label: q_ed04_q11_longitudinal
content:
{
  "question_id": "ed04_q11_longitudinal",
  "scope_id": "environmental_drift_04",
  "checkpoint_after": 20,
  "question_type": "longitudinal",
  "prompt": "What does the spatial distribution of heavy metal readings reveal about contamination?",
  "ground_truth": {
    "canonical_answer": "A clear point-source contamination pattern: WQ-01 and WQ-02 remain at baseline while WQ-03 shows peak chromium concentrations with progressive dilution downstream. The source is between WQ-02 and WQ-03. Agricultural runoff explains turbidity but not the chromium gradient.",
    "required_evidence_refs": [
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_016",
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_017",
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_020"
    ],
    "key_facts": [
      "progressive chromium concentration decay from peak station to downstream sites indicates single-source contamination",
      "discharge source identifiable between last clean upstream station and first elevated station in monitoring network",
      "stations upstream of the anomaly source maintain background-level trace metal readings throughout the study",
      "seasonal nutrient loading explains turbidity spikes but not hexavalent metal signature",
      "the contamination signature is hexavalent chromium from an industrial point source, not agricultural nutrient runoff",
      "atmospheric deposition is not contributing to the water contamination \u2014 the chromium source is a direct discharge into the waterway",
      "the contamination pathway is surface-water discharge, not groundwater migration, as evidenced by the sharp spatial concentration gradient"
    ]
  }
}
